meaning: A larger type of cell that contains a nucleus storing genetic information. Found in plants and animals.
A smaller type of cell storing genetic material as a DNA loop, which may have one or two rings of DNA known as plasmids.
An organelle found in eukaryotic cells that contains genetic material.
The fluid that fills cells, consisting of water and solutes.
The partially permeable membrane that controls what enters and leaves a cell
An organelle where respiration occurs
An organelle responsible for protein synthesis
An organelle found in plant cells that is responsible for photosynthesis
An organelle found in plant cells that stores cell sap
The outer cellulose layer of plant and algal cells responsible for strengthening the cell.
A cell that has adapted to carry out a particular function
A sub-cellular structure specialised for a particular function
The process where an unspecialised stem cell gains individual characteristics and functions
A type of DNA structure found in the nucleus of a cell, usually in pairs
A section of a chromosome.
An undifferentiated cell capable of creating specialised cells of a certain type.
A type of stem cell found in embryos, capable of differentiating into almost all kinds of cell found in the human body
A type of stem cell found in adults, capable of differentiating into many kinds of cell found in the human body
A region of unspecialised cells in a plant capable of mitosis at any point throughout the plant's life
The process where a single cell divides to produce two genetically identical 'daughter' cells
A process where an embryo is produced which has the same genes as a patient. Its stem cells will not be rejected by the body
The series of stages which a cell goes through as it grows and divides, including mitosis.
The process by which particles spread out, resulting in a net movement from high concentration to low concentration
The process by which water molecules diffuse through a partially permeable membrane from a dilute solution to a concentrated one
The process by which substances move through a partially permeable membrane, using energy from respiration to move against the concentration gradient.
